channel.title: NASA Image of the Day
channel.description: The latest NASA "Image of the Day" image.

item.title: Expedition 61 Soyuz Rollout
item.description: The gantry arms close around the Soyuz rocket after it was raised into vertical position on the launch pad, Monday, Sept. 23, 2019 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

item.title: Hubble Takes Closer Look at Not-So-'Dead' Neighbor
item.description: Because they lack stellar nurseries and contain mostly old stars, elliptical galaxies — Like Messier 110 — are often considered “dead” when compared to their spiral relatives. But scientists have spotted signs of a population of young, blue stars at Messier 110's center, hinting that this neighbor of our Milky Way may not be so “dead” after all.

item.title: Layers in Mars' Danielson Crater
item.description: This image shows sedimentary rock and sand within Danielson Crater, an impact crater about 42 miles or 67 kilometers in diameter, located in the southwest Arabia Terra region of Mars.

item.title: Space Station Downlink with Actor Brad Pitt
item.description: Actor Brad Pitt speaks with NASA astronaut Nick Hague who is onboard the International Space Station, Monday, Sept. 16, 2019.

item.title: Franklin Chang-Diaz Performs a Spacewalk on the STS-111 Mission
item.description: In this mage from June 2002, astronaut Franklin R. Chang-Diaz works with a grapple fixture during a spacewalk to perform work on the International Space Station.

item.title: Mae Jemison Trains for Her Space Shuttle Flight
item.description: Mae Jemison, the first black woman in space, participated in crew egress training for Space Shuttle Endeavour's STS-47 mission during the Terminal Countdown Demonstration Test.

item.title: Remembering September 11th and Looking to the Future
item.description: This 2019 photo of Manhattan, taken by astronaut Nick Hague from aboard the International Space Station, shows a city totally recovered from the attack on September 11, 2001.

item.title: Testing and Training on the Boeing Starliner
item.description: NASA astronaut Mike Fincke works through a check list inside a mockup of Boeing's CST-100 Starliner during a simulation at NASA's Johnson Space Center on Aug. 21, 2019.

item.title: Learning to Track Water Using NASA Satellite Data
item.description: It's Back to School Week and NASA has activities to keep students motivated.

item.title: Clues for Mars in the Australian Outback
item.description: Scientists with NASA's Mars 2020 mission and the European-Russian ExoMars mission traveled to the Australian Outback to hone their research techniques.

item.title: Satellite Captures Four Tropical Cyclones from Space
item.description: On Sept. 4, 2019, a loose chain of tropical cyclones lined up across the Western Hemisphere.

item.title: An Infrared View of the M81 Galaxy
item.description: Located in the northern constellation of Ursa Major, which also includes the Big Dipper, nearby galaxy Messier 81 is easily visible through binoculars or a small telescope.

item.title: Jessica Meir Climbs Aboard a Soyuz Trainer
item.description: At the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center in Star City, Russia, Expedition 61 crewmember Jessica Meir of NASA climbs aboard a Soyuz trainer during final crew qualification exams on Aug. 30.

item.title: Hurricane Dorian Seen From Aboard the Space Station
item.description: NASA astronaut Christian Koch snapped this image of Hurricane Dorian as the International Space Station during a flyover on Monday, September 2, 2019.

item.title: Hubble Views Final Stages of a Star’s Life
item.description: NGC 5307, a planetary nebula that lies about 10,000 light-years from Earth, can be seen in the constellation Centaurus.

item.title: Celebrating Spitzer's Sweet Sixteen
item.description: Spitzer Space Telescope into orbit around the Sun on Aug. 25, 2003. Since then, the observatory has been lifting the veil on the wonders of the cosmos, from our own solar system to faraway galaxies, using infrared light.

item.title: Lifting the Space Launch System Core Stage Into Place
item.description: NASA cleared a milestone in preparation for Green Run testing of its Space Launch System (SLS) core stage with the lift and installation of the core stage pathfinder simulator onto the B-2 Test Stand.

item.title: Astronaut Andrew Morgan Performs His First Spacewalk
item.description: West Point graduate, physician and NASA astronaut Andrew Morgan is pictured working outside the International Space Station .

item.title: Christine Darden: From Human Computer to Engineer
item.description: In 1967, Christine Darden was added to the pool of 'human computers' who wrote complex programs and tediously crunched numbers for engineers at NASA's Langley Research Center.

item.title: Hubble Captures Dynamic Dying Star
item.description: This Hubble image shows a dark, gloomy scene in the constellation of Gemini (the Twins). The subject of this image confused astronomers when it was first studied — rather than being classified as a single object, it was instead recorded as two objects, owing to its symmetrical lobed structure.

item.title: Wildfires in the Brazilian Rainforest Creating Cross Country Smoke
item.description: Amazon rainforest fires causing smoke to drift across the whole of Brazil.

item.title: A View of the National Space Council
item.description: A member of the audience takes a picture with their phone as Vice President Mike Pence is introduced during the sixth meeting of the National Space Council.

item.title: SpaceX Dragon Crew Emergency Evacuation Rehearsal
item.description: A quick moving storm passes as teams from NASA and SpaceX practice procedures for medical emergency evacuation onboard the GO Searcher ship, Friday, August 15, 2019.

item.title: 3D Printing and the Future of Aeronautics
item.description: Today is National Aviation Day and progress is ongoing in the next evolution of air mobility – all thanks to emerging 3D printing technology.

item.title: Hubble’s Portrait of Star’s Gaseous Glow
item.description: Although it looks more like an entity seen through a microscope than a telescope, this rounded object, named NGC 2022, is certainly not algae or tiny, blobby jellyfish. Instead, it is a vast orb of gas in space, cast off by an aging star.

item.title: NASA and SpaceX: Dragon Crew Extraction Rehearsal
item.description: On August 13, 2019, NASA astronauts Doug Hurley, left, and Bob Behnken continue to work with teams from NASA and SpaceX to rehearse crew extraction from SpaceX’s Crew Dragon.

item.title: Studying How Arctic Wildfires Change the World
item.description: Standing among dead black spruce trees in a burned area near Delta Junction, Richard Chen dug soil sampling pits throughout the burned area.

item.title: A Full Moon Over the Pacific
item.description: The crew of the International Space Station snapped this image of a full Moon as the orbiting complex flew 270 miles above the South Pacific Ocean off the coast of South America.

item.title: One Year of NASA's Parker Solar Probe
item.description: The Parker Solar Probe's WISPR instrument saw the solar wind streaming past during the spacecraft's first solar encounter in November 2018.

item.title: Hubble Catches 2 Galaxies at Play
item.description: This galactic duo is known as UGC 2369. The galaxies are interacting, meaning that their mutual gravitational attraction is pulling them closer and closer together and distorting their shapes in the process.

item.title: Hubble Spots Jupiter’s Great Red Spot
item.description: This new Hubble Space Telescope view of Jupiter, taken on June 27, 2019, reveals the giant planet's trademark Great Red Spot, and a more intense color palette in the clouds swirling in Jupiter's turbulent atmosphere than seen in previous years.

item.title: Seven Years After Landing, Curiosity Rover is Still Rock N' Rolling
item.description: Our Curiosity rover has come a long way since touching down on Mars seven years ago. It has traveled a total of 13 miles (21 kilometers) and ascended 1,207 feet (368 meters) to its current location.

item.title: Our Sun Today
item.description: NASA's Solar Dynamic Observatory, or SDO, was the first mission to be launched for NASA's Living With a Star (LWS) Program, and is designed to understand the causes of solar variability and its impacts on Earth.

item.title: One Small Step: The Legacy of Neil Armstrong
item.description: Born on August 5, 1930, Neil Armstrong was a man of many accomplishments and when he landed on the Moon, he walked into the history books.

item.title: Mariner 6 and 7 Explore the Red Planet
item.description: Lost in the glare following the Apollo 11 Moon landing, two intrepid robotic spacecraft flew by Mars in the summer of 1969 and returned photographs and a trove of scientific information.

item.title: Colonel Raja Chari: NASA Astronaut Candidate
item.description: NASA astronaut candidate Raja Chari climbs into a NASA T-38 aircraft.

item.title: This Week in NASA History: First Use of the Lunar Roving Vehicle – July 31, 1971
item.description: This week in 1971, Apollo 15 became the first mission to use the Lunar Roving Vehicle.

item.title: Viewing the Mediterranean Coasts of Tunisia and Libya from the Space Station
item.description: The Mediterranean coasts of Tunisia and Libya and the Italian island of Sicily across the sea are pictured as the International Space Station orbited 260 miles above north Africa.

item.title: NASA Pilot Rich Rogers: "All Good Things ..."
item.description: For NASA Wallops Flight Facility research pilot Rich Rogers, July 26 brought an end to one of the things in his life that he has greatly enjoyed – flying Navy and NASA aircraft.

item.title: Hubble Snaps a Galactic Potpourri of Particles
item.description: The sharply angled perspective in this Hubble image of spiral galaxy NGC 3169 makes it seem as if we, the viewers, are craning our necks to see over a barrier into the galaxy's bright center. In the case of NGC 3169, this barrier is the thick dust embedded within the galaxy's spiral arms.

item.title: Seeing the World With a Drone
item.description: A drone moves high above downtown Reno, Nevada on the afternoon of June 23, 2019 as part of NASA’s TCL-4 (Technology Capability Level) operation.

item.title: 50 Years Ago Today: Apollo 11 Command Module Recovered After Splashdown
item.description: The Apollo 11 Command Module is hoisted aboard the USS Hornet, the prime recovery vessel for the historic Apollo 11 lunar landing mission.

item.title: Christopher Kraft at Flight Console
item.description: Christopher C. Kraft, Jr., who died July 22, 2019, created the concept of NASA's Mission Control and developed its organization, operational procedures and culture

item.title: Visions of Apollo 11: Command Service Module Orbits the Moon
item.description: This image shows the Command Service Module orbiting the Moon as Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin explored the lunar surface.

item.title: Apollo 11 and Landing Site 2 in the Sea of Tranquility
item.description: This photographic illustration compares the size of Apollo 11 Landing Site 2 with that of the metropolitan New York City area.

item.title: Soyuz Heads to the Launch Pad in Black and White
item.description: In this black and white infrared image, the Soyuz rocket is seen as it transported to the launch pad by train, Thursday, July 18, 2019 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

item.title: Apollo 11 Astronaut Michael Collins Talks to Apollo 11 and Artemis 1 Launch Teams
item.description: Then and Now: Apollo 11 astronaut Michael Collins talks to Apollo 11 and Artemis 1 Launch Teams in Firing Room 1 at Kennedy Space Center.

item.title: 50 Years Ago Apollo 11 Launches Into History
item.description: At 9:32 a.m. EDT, July 16, 1969, Apollo 11 launched from Florida on a mission to the Moon.

item.title: Artist Russ Arasmith's Visions of Apollo
item.description: Artist Russ Arasmith's vision of Apollo was a potent vision of the program that shows in the works he created.

item.title: Hubble Peers at Galactic Cherry Blossoms
item.description: The galaxy NGC 1156 resembles a delicate cherry blossom tree flowering in springtime in this Hubble image. The many bright "blooms" within the galaxy are in fact stellar nurseries — regions where new stars are springing to life.

item.title: Delivering Saturn Test Hardware to Marshall in July 1964
item.description: In July 1964, the first Saturn V S-IVB, or third stage test hardware, was delivered to NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center

item.title: Growing VEGGIEs in Space
item.description: Leafy greens are growing in space!

item.title: Jupiter Abyss
item.description: NASA’s Juno spacecraft captured this view of an area within a Jovian jet stream showing a vortex that has an intensely dark center.

item.title: Total Solar Eclipse Darkens the South Pacific
item.description: On July 2, 2019, skywatchers in the beach city of La Serena, Chile, looked up at 4:38 p.m. local time to see a black circle in the sky.

item.title: Earth's Glow, the Moon and a Starry Night
item.description: This was the view as the International Space Station orbited 256 miles above the Pacific Ocean, southeast of the Hawaiian island chain.

item.title: NASA's First Rover on the Red Planet
item.description: This 8-image mosaic of the Sojourner rover on the surface of Mars was acquired during the late afternoon on Sol 2. Sojourner arrived aboard the Mars Pathfinder on July 4, 1997.

item.title: Taking to the Skies: Orion Test Brings Moon, Mars Missions Closer
item.description: A launch abort system (LAS) with a test version of Orion attached soars upward on NASA’s Ascent Abort-2 (AA-2) flight test atop a Northrop Grumman provided booster on July 2, 2019, after launching at 7 a.m. EDT.

item.title: Orion "Go" for Launch
item.description: A test version of NASA’s Orion crew module is ready for rollback at Space Launch Complex 46 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida.

item.title: Last Test Article for NASA’s SLS Rocket Departs Michoud Assembly Facility
item.description: The last of four structural test articles for NASA’s Space Launch System (SLS) was loaded onto NASA’s barge Pegasus Wednesday, June 26, 2019, at NASA’s Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans.

item.title: Tumultuous Clouds of Jupiter
item.description: This stunning image of Jupiter's stormy northern hemisphere was captured by NASA's Juno spacecraft as it performed a close pass of the gas giant planet.
